title: Gallstone Pancreatitis
diagnosis_topic: Acute pancreatitis triggered by transient obstruction of the common bile duct by gallstones
setup_script: A 40-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe epigastric pain radiating to her back. She reports associated nausea and several episodes of vomiting. She has a known history of gallstones. On exam, she appears uncomfortable. How would you proceed?

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 110/70 mmHg, HR 105 bpm, RR 20/min, Temp 37.9 °C.
Epigastric tenderness without rebound; no jaundice initially.
Serum lipase 800 U/L (elevated), AST/ALT moderately elevated, bilirubin 2.0 mg/dL.
Gallstones present in gallbladder, common bile duct slightly dilated, no stone visualized.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident initiates IV hydration and analgesia
dynamic_flow.reply: Lactated Ringer’s infusion started, pain managed with opioids; patient reports improvement in pain.
NG tube placed for persistent vomiting; symptoms partially improve.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident consults GI for ERCP
dynamic_flow.reply: GI notes no evidence of cholangitis; ERCP not performed immediately.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident delays cholecystectomy until pancreatitis resolves
dynamic_flow.reply: Patient improves clinically; early laparoscopic cholecystectomy during index admission is planned.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident prematurely attempts cholecystectomy during acute attack
dynamic_flow.reply: Patient’s pain worsens, requiring procedure to be postponed.
No necrosis or pseudocyst seen on imaging; systemic inflammatory response resolves.
Ranson criteria calculated; predicts mild disease, no ICU required.
Patient has recurrent pain and vomiting; diet is held and restarted once symptoms resolve.
Patient advised on low-fat diet and alcohol avoidance; counseled on recurrence risk.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident proceeds to surgery and is asked to describe operative details
dynamic_flow.reply: Please describe your operative approach for laparoscopic cholecystectomy, including critical steps, intraoperative cholangiography considerations, and management of potential complications.

critical_decision_points: Recognition of gallstone pancreatitis based on history, labs, and imaging.
Early fluid resuscitation and pain control.
Assessment of need for ERCP versus conservative management.
Monitoring for complications and avoiding unnecessary antibiotics.
Knowledge and description of operative steps in laparoscopic cholecystectomy.

rubric.resident_feedback_template: Strengths: You demonstrated strong diagnostic reasoning by promptly identifying gallstone pancreatitis and initiating appropriate resuscitation. Your plan for early laparoscopic cholecystectomy during the index admission was appropriate. Communication of your management approach was clear and organized. Areas for Improvement: Further clarity is needed in distinguishing which patients require urgent ERCP. Ensure dietary advancement is based on clinical recovery rather than timing alone. Review the role of antibiotics and avoid unnecessary use unless infection is documented. Provide more detail when describing the operative steps of laparoscopic cholecystectomy.
